Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: The ambulance is transporting a critically ill patient through a severe thunderstorm with slick roads and low visibility.
Story:
I gripped the steering wheel tighter as rain hammered the windshield, the wipers barely keeping up. The siren wailed, echoing my own racing heart. In the back, the paramedic shouted updates about the patient’s dropping blood pressure. Every second counted, but the roads were slick, visibility almost nothing. I had to keep the ambulance steady, safe—lives depended on it.

My phone buzzed in my pocket, a familiar vibration. I knew it was my mom. She always texted on weekends, just to check in, to make sure I was okay. I hadn’t replied to her last message yet. I could almost hear her voice, worried, hoping for a quick “I’m fine, love you.” I wanted to reassure her, to be the son she expected—present, communicative, caring.

But right now, my hands were needed on the wheel, my focus on the road and the fragile life behind me. The urge to grab my phone, to send a quick text, gnawed at me. I felt torn, pulled between the duty to my patient and the love for my mother, both expecting something I wasn’t sure I could give at the same time.
